disobedience.question: Was I disobedient to parents in my actions?
disobedience.description: As per the fourth commandment, it's a child's duty to respond to parental love, wisdom, and respect with obedience.

extracted_data_phrases: by refusing to listen to their counsel or follow their guidance
disobedience.question: Was I disobedient to my parents by refusing to listen to their counsel or follow their guidance?
disobedience.description: As per the fourth commandment, it's a child's duty to respond to parental love, wisdom, and respect with obedience.

extracted_data_phrases: to those entrusted with my care
disobedience.question: Was I disobedient to those entrusted with my care?
disobedience.description: As per the fourth commandment, it's a child's duty to respond to parental love, wisdom, and respect with obedience.

disobedience.question: Did I reject the unity of the Church when frustrated by individuals within my community?
disobedience.description: Rejecting Church unity due to frustration with individuals is sinful because it confuses the Church's divine nature and eternal truths with the human imperfections of its members, while also violating Christ's prayer "that they may all be one."

condoning.question: Did I encourage other Catholics to remain absent from Sacraments or Mass?
condoning.description: One of the spiritual works of mercy is to admonish the sinner and to correct them out of love and charity instead of condoning sin.

condoning.question: Did I allow other Catholics to remain absent from Sacraments or Mass without correcting them?
condoning.description: One of the spiritual works of mercy is to admonish the sinner and to correct them out of love and charity instead of condoning sin.

extracted_data_phrases: from participating in sacraments by my words
condoning.question: Did I lead fellow Catholics astray from participating in sacraments by my words?
condoning.description: One of the spiritual works of mercy is to admonish the sinner and to correct them out of love and charity instead of condoning sin.

condoning.question: Have I allowed my desire for human validation to lead me to compromise my beliefs rather than upholding what I know is right?
condoning.description: Prioritizing human approval over standing firm in God's truth demonstrates both moral cowardice and places human opinion above divine authority.

condoning.question: Did you condone a funeral where human remains were not properly buried?
condoning.description: Failing to advocate for proper burial of human remains is considered sinful as the Church teaches that the body is sacred and deserves reverent burial, with scattering or keeping remains being contrary to the dignity of the human body and resurrection belief.

condoning.question: Did I intentionally permit those in my life to be exposed to bad influences?
condoning.description: Parents have to protect their children's well-being, guarding them from harmful elements that could damage their faith or lead them into sin.

condoning.question: Did I give my approval to another Catholic who was planning to marry outside the Church?
condoning.description: Marriage is a sacrament within the Catholic faith and thus giving approval and not admonishing the action gives scandal by condoning.

extracted_data_phrases: by remaining silent when they considered marrying someone outside the Church
condoning.question: Did I give my approval to another Catholic by remaining silent when they considered marrying someone outside the Church?
condoning.description: Marriage is a sacrament within the Catholic faith and thus giving approval and not admonishing the action gives scandal by condoning.

extracted_data_phrases: through my words to another Catholic who chose to marry outside of the Church
to another Catholic who chose to marry outside of the Church
condoning.question: Did I give tacit approval through my words to another Catholic who chose to marry outside of the Church?
condoning.description: Marriage is a sacrament within the Catholic faith and thus giving approval and not admonishing the action gives scandal by condoning.

condoning.question: Did I allow my work habits to disrupt the rest and worship that others, especially those in positions of authority, observe on Sundays?
condoning.description: It's irreverent to work on a Sunday as it's a holy day of rest, worship, and a day of protest against the servitude of work and the worship of money (CCC).

extracted_data_phrases: from those who are homeless , displaced , or in need

uncharity.description: Per the corporal works of mercy, we are to love our neighbors by feeding the hungry and sheltering the homeless and respecting their dignity especially in times of hardship.

in need , strangers , and displaced individuals

on their job , nationality , or other trait that is beyond my control

uncharity.description: This sin dehumanizes people on the margins when we are called to love each other as a child of God as Jesus loved us.

extracted_data_phrases: based on their job , nationality , or other trait
on their job , nationality , or other trait

uncharity.description: This is considered sinful because excessive self-focus and selfishness violates Christ's command to love our neighbors as ourselves and contradicts the Christian call to practice charity, compassion, and self-sacrifice for others.

uncharity.question: Did I allow my own desires and needs to overshadow the genuine concerns and well-being of those around me?
uncharity.description: This is considered sinful because excessive self-focus and selfishness violates Christ's command to love our neighbors as ourselves and contradicts the Christian call to practice charity, compassion, and self-sacrifice for others.

uncharity.question: Did I permit someone else to suffer injustice or be treated unfairly?
uncharity.description: This sin violates the principles of justice, charity, and our moral obligation to defend human dignity and protect our neighbors from harm when we have the ability to intervene.

uncharity.question: Did I stand idly by while someone was treated unfairly?
uncharity.description: This sin violates the principles of justice, charity, and our moral obligation to defend human dignity and protect our neighbors from harm when we have the ability to intervene.

extracted_data_phrases: for someone who was being treated unfairly

uncharity.description: This sin violates the principles of justice, charity, and our moral obligation to defend human dignity and protect our neighbors from harm when we have the ability to intervene.

uncharity.question: Have I been unwilling to lend assistance when someone genuinely needed it?
uncharity.description: Refusing to help those in need violates Jesus's direct command to love our neighbor and practice the works of mercy, as illustrated in the parable of the Good Samaritan.

extracted_data_phrases: such as strangers on the street or acquaintances facing financial struggles

uncharity.description: Failing to help those in need violates Christ's direct command to love our neighbor and care for the poor, effectively refusing to recognize Jesus Himself in the suffering of others.

uncharity.question: Have I shown compassion and practical assistance to those in my community who are experiencing financial hardship or other forms of need?
uncharity.description: Failing to help those in need violates Christ's direct command to love our neighbor and care for the poor, effectively refusing to recognize Jesus Himself in the suffering of others.

extracted_data_phrases: particularly during times of hardship or unexpected expenses

uncharity.description: Failing to help those in need violates Christ's direct command to love our neighbor and care for the poor, effectively refusing to recognize Jesus Himself in the suffering of others.

lukewarmness.question: Am I indifferent to personal spiritual growth, content to maintain my current level of faith development?
lukewarmness.description: Lukewarmness in spiritual growth is sinful because one essentially chooses comfort and mediocrity over the transformative love God offers, which Jesus specifically warned against in Revelation 3:16.

merciless.question: Have I spoken against others, judging them in my words?
merciless.description: Condemning others is a sin of mercilessness because it places oneself in God's role as judge and denies others the same mercy and forgiveness that God extends to all of us.

merciless.question: Did I use my words to judge others harshly?

callousness.question: Did I neglect to assist someone who was suffering financially when I had the means to provide aid?

sloth.question: Have I neglected to lead my child in spiritual growth, potentially hindering their journey towards Christ?

vainglory.question: Did I give alms so others would see me doing it?
